Definition: HyperText Markup Language, the standard markup language used to create web pages.
Cascading Style Sheets, used to style and layout web pages.
A high-level, interpreted programming language that is a core technology of the World Wide Web.
The client side of a web application, typically consisting of HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.
The server side of a web application, responsible for managing data, server requests, and more.
A system that stores, processes, and delivers web pages to users.
Hypertext Transfer Protocol, the protocol used for transferring data over the web.
Uniform Resource Locator, the address used to access web resources.
Search Engine Optimization, the practice of increasing the quantity and quality of traffic to your website through organic search engine results.
Application Programming Interface, a set of rules that allow programs to talk to each other.
JavaScript Object Notation, a format for structuring data.
An approach to web design that makes web pages render well on a variety of devices and window or screen sizes.
A set of tools built into modern browsers that developers can use to probe and experiment with web pages.
A distributed version control system for tracking changes in source code during software development.
A web-based hosting service for version control and collaboration using Git.
A text-based user interface to a computer's operating system.
Node Package Manager, a package manager for the JavaScript programming language.
A package manager for the JavaScript programming language that helps to manage project dependencies.
A platform built on Chrome's JavaScript runtime for building fast and scalable network applications.
A minimal and flexible Node.js web application framework that provides a robust set of features for web and mobile applications.
Representational State Transfer, an architectural style for designing networked applications.
A structured set of data stored and organized in a way that allows for efficient retrieval, modification, and deletion of the data.
Structured Query Language, a programming language used to communicate with and manipulate databases.
A non-relational database that provides a mechanism for storage and retrieval of data modeled in means other than tabular relations used in relational databases.
Document Object Model, a programming interface for web documents.
An action or occurrence recognized by a program that may be handled by the program.
Asynchronous JavaScript and XML, a set of web development techniques for creating asynchronous web applications.
The practice of delivering optimized images to users based on their device capabilities and screen size.
The ability of a website or web application to function across different web browsers.
The process of finding and resolving errors or issues in code.
A collection of pre-written, standardized code that facilitates the development of web applications.
A collection of pre-written, standardized code that facilitates the development of server-side applications.
A web application or website that interacts with the user by dynamically rewriting the current web page with new data from the web server.
The overall experience a user has when interacting with a product or system, especially in terms of how easy or pleasing it is to use.
The means by which a user interacts with a computer or other electronic device.
The process of verifying the identity of a user or system.
The process of granting or denying access to resources or services based on user identity and permissions.
The process of securely managing user interactions with a web application across multiple requests and responses.
The process of encoding information in such a way that only authorized parties can access it.
A security vulnerability that allows attackers to inject malicious scripts into web pages viewed by other users.
A security vulnerability that allows an attacker to exploit the trust that a website has for a user's browser.
The ability of a system to handle growing amounts of work in a graceful manner.
The process of improving the speed and efficiency of a web application.
An approach to web design that aims to make web pages render well on a variety of devices and window or screen sizes.
A type of application software delivered through the web, built using common web technologies like HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.
The practice of ensuring that websites and web applications are usable by people of all abilities and disabilities.
Measurements used to evaluate the performance of a web application, such as page load time, response time, and resource utilization.
The practice of regularly merging code changes from multiple developers into a shared repository.
The practice of automatically deploying code changes to production environments after passing automated tests.
A distributed network of servers that deliver web content to users based on their geographic location, server availability, and performance metrics.
